editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Non ſatis inſidiis est admiranda Virago.
LONDON. Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke; and are to be ſold at his Shop, at the Greene Dragon, in Pauls Church-yard. 1640.

div.head: To his vvorthy Friend, Mr. Robert Chamberlaine on His Swaggering Damſell.
div.l: WHat pretty humor was thy Muſe in when,
She put on Breeches, and the dreſſe of men;
Caſting aſide her Robe, embroyder'd thicke,
With Lawrell ſprigges, and Flowers of Rhetoricke;
Or what conceit had Mercurie, when he,
Made uſe of Venus Looking-glaſſe to ſee
How his ſhape femall did become him, ſure
She tainted him being her ſelfe impure;
No, ſhe is chaſte, and in her geniall bed,
Hermes himſelfe would looſe his Maidenhead:
Cupid has ſtuft her pillow with looſe haires,
Pluckt from his ſilken curles, and oft repaires
Vnto her Slumbers with a balmy kiſſe,
Charming her braine to teeme with love like His.
Her ſheets are ſweetly ayr'd, and ſpun ſo fine,
Ladyes may have worſe lodging, light thy Pine
Then glorious Hymen, at our Damſells eyes,
That ſhe may ſhine in her ſolemnities,
And dazell her detractors, thou choice Friend,
Shall give me leave with juſtice to commend;
Thy paines to the Pierides, thy hand,
Shalt dreſſe their bankes and bowers, untill the Land
Grow fertill as thy Fancy, for thy parts,
Have made a conqueſt of a thouſand hearts.

div.head: To his deſerving Friend, Mr. Robert Chamberlaine upon his Swaggering Damſell.
div.l: FRiend, when my Ʋeſſell from the narrow ſtage,
Lanch'd to this wider Ocean, where the rage
Of madding Cenſure met her, Thou didſt play
The part of a skill'd Pilot calm'ſt the way:
Nor envy with her ſtrongeſt winds durſt ſtirre,
Knowing (Skill'd Navigator) thou guid'ſt her;
I dare not boaſt, like Art, yet hope to prove
Commended, ſince I ſtrive to quit thy love
In the acknowledgement, and offer theſe
To thy Faire Damſell's welfare, may ſhe pleaſe
Thoſe that have judging ſoules; and to the reſt
That hate Dramaticke Lawes, as is your teſt
Vnto their faith, that's hatefull, for they be
Counted in ſhew, not prove their puritie:
This glory for to ſuffer their dull rage,
And be cry'd up the glory of the Stage.

div.head: To his Deſerving friend Mr. Robert Chamberlaine upon his Swaggering Damſell.
div.l: YOur Swagg'ring Damſell you moſt aptly Fit,
To the ſweete Harmony of Art, and Wit,
Your Pen hath taught all women to begin,
A new; yet civill way to Swagger in;
Our natures you have chang'd, and men adore,
The ſelfe-ſame thing which they did hate before;
A woman Cavellier, nor is your Muſe,
In forfeiting her modeſty profuſe;
No debaucht Scenes, nor ſuch baſe mirth as we
Place in the Scenes, of obſcene Ribaldry,
Pollutes they Pen, thy happy influence,
Virgins may read with a ſafe innocence:
And ſhall applaud thee as one borne to be,
The ſole reſtorer of their liberty.

list.item: SIr Timothy Testy; an old angry decayed Knight.
Sir Plenteous Crambagge, an old Vſurer.
Valentine Crambagge, Sonne to Sir Plenteous, and Lover of Sabina.
Fairefaith, Kinſman to Valentine, and Lover of Mirabell.
Hilts, A blunt fellow, Servant to ſir Timothy.
Traſh, Clowne, and Servant to Valentine.
Welt, His Wife, A Shoomaker, at whoſe houſe Valentine lay in the time of his diſguiſe.
Roger and Rowland, Servants to ſir Plenteous.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: FAire ſtars attend this preſence, Gentlemen,
Our Author bids me bid ye welcome, then
Our houſe bids welcome, I my ſelfe agen,
Well, then at once thrice welcome Gentlemen.
But firſt, to you whoſe education brings
Learning along wee't for to judge of things;
I ſpeake, but what needs that, your natures ſuch,
That with nice Criticiſme it ſcornes to touch.
Ladies for you, I reade it in each front;
You will, nay more, you muſt looke faire upon't,
How ere, we hope, that all your ſmiles will be,
Propitious to our labours, not that wee,
Foreſtall your judgements, or doe begge applauſe,
Thats not our meaning, we have no ſuch cauſe;
Yet doe beleeve, you will your Candors bring,
Cauſe 'tis the Primroſe of the Authors Spring.

div.head: Actus 1. Scena 1.
div.stage: Enter Hiles, Roger, and Rowland; Roger with a Napkin on his ſleeve, and a ſilver bowle in's hand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: COme Hilts, one cup more.

sp.speaker: Hilts,
sp.p: Not a drop, I know they have din'd by this time, and if I ſhu'd be out oth' way, when my maſter comes, he would raile, that the noyſe of an Oyſter wench wu'd not be halfe ſo diveliſh.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Come, come, one luſtie diſh now ith' bottome oth' cellar's worth all the reſt —

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: A way with your number 4. it makes rattle-bagges and windmills in my guts, I cannot endure it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come, come, I warrant ye, it will not, prethee come.

sp.speaker: Hilt.
sp.p: Not? Why I'me blowne wee't already like a Lancaſhire Bag-pipe upon a May day; and beſides, tis ſo weake, that a man cannot keepe it alive while he throwes it in's guts, when thou comſt' to our houſe Ile give thee a cup of Beere will make thy noſe cry twang Roger.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Why, but ye doe not keepe ſuch a houſe for all your jeſting, doe ye?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Such a houſe, ſhat come in a morning, and finde the cellar a foote deepe in March beere; here a blacke Jacke, and there a ſlagon ſtanding in't like ſteeples in a drown'd city — Ther's houſe-keeping Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I marry ſir, there's a houſe well kept indeede.

sp.speaker: Hilts▪
sp.p: Nay ſir, by this meanes we make my Maſter a better houſe keeper than ere his father or grandfather was before him; for where they were us'd to ride every day a Hawking and hunting, my Maſter keepes the houſe ſometimes for two or three yeares together, and what's the cauſe? nothing but our mirth, our randans, our tarra tantaras — oh the onely way in the world to make a gentleman a houſe-keeper.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, come, I muſt needs have our round about to thy Maſters daughters; for doſt heare Hilts, me thought there was a little nodding and winking betwixt my young Maſter, Mr. Ʋalentine Crambag, and Miſtreſſe Sabina, didſt not perceive it Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Yes marry did I, and tother gentleman there his Kinſman me thought now and then caſt a ſheepes eye towards Miſtreſſe Mirabell; goe to, an old Ape has an old Eye, Roger.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why but Roger you are not ſuch a Sillibraine, I hope to thinke that your young Maſter loves Miſtriſſe Sabina —

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I me paſt thinking, for I doe partly know it.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, tis neither impoſſible nor unlikely?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I doe not beleeve your young Maſter's ſuch a ſtout fellow Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why pray?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p:
I meane, as to venture himſelfe upon ſuch a wilde thing, I tell you ſirs, your young Maſter, I confeſſe is a pretty dappart young gentleman, but in reſpect of her he is but a Child, a ſhrimpe, a Butterflie, a Chitterling, a Bable; in love with her quoth a? Shee's not one that cares for complements, or will be wonne with cringes, or your tres-humble ſerviteur Madame; no no Roger; ſhe is a Blade, a Sparke, a Teare-coate; and he that carries her away, muſt mumble her, jumble her,
rumble her, and tumble her, ſwagger, roare, and teare like a mad man; your young Maſter quoth a? — piſh,

div.stage: To them Ʋalentine and Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Huſht, here come the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Why ſtand you here? make ſir Timothy Teſties man welcome — go.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: It was a brave ſpeech of your worſhips ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Coſen, Exit with Rog. and Row.
The wombe of Aetnas but a rocke of ice,
Compar'd unto thoſe flames that rage within
My boſome;
I muſt enjoy, or elſe give end unto
This mortall life by ſome untimely meanes.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Good ſtarres forbid it ſir;
Come, come,
Lull not your owne deſtruction, nor unman
Your ſelfe in doting on the outward frame
Of an imperfect ſoule,
Follow diſcretions finger that will guide
Your underſtanding and your minde to one,
Whoſe perſon's vertues Temple;
Coſen thinke on't,
Her qualities and yours will ne're agree;
Your civill nature ne're will correſpond
With her wanton humours.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: It cannot be,
There's nothing ſave a Deity can inhabit
So glorious a manſion,
Not love her, ſay yee? not have her;
I hope my ſtarres will never looke ſo blacke,
How ever yet my comforts this,
If I cannot have her I can periſh.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: That caſe is deſperate, when a man muſt needs
Sinke in a gulfe, or ſplit upon the rocke;
Know ſir, I beare as good a mind
To her faire ſiſter Mirabell; but yet
I checke theſe paſſions fearing that ſhee is
Too like her ſiſter, yet my flames doe riſe
So high, that ſhe takes notice on't; come
Learne to forget her, for you muſt expect
Nothing from her but ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That ſuch a creature has ſo foule a ſoule,
'Twill never pierce
My underſtanding judgement, or beleefe;
Her birth and education needs muſt purge
Such groſſeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir be happie, hugge your owne fancy,
May things prove well, I ſhall be glad to ſee't;
Farre bee't from me to envie any good
Betydes a friend and kinſman. To them Sabina Mirabell.
Peace, they'r both come.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Welcome faire one,
Welcome I fay, toth' armes of him that flies,
All joyes but thoſe that in thy boſome lies.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: My boſome? what dee you finde there pray ſir; you have a minde perhappes to my Jewell, if you will not hurt it, ye ſhall have it a while to play with, tis a pretty bright thing ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not ſo bright as your white boſome, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: As how pray ye? what ſee you there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no, the gods wu'd frowne if any mortall breath,
Shu'd once prophane that milkie way,
There's not a little in that lovely place,
But does create a wonder:
When Cupid's thirſtie, and deſires a ſip,
Of Nectar, than he runnes unto thy lip,
And for your haire, the brightneſſe of it does
Perſwade my ſoule the very graces ſpun
The golden twiſt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray yee ſpeake on ſir, when ye have emptied your pockets youle be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Emptied my pockets?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Sir, theſe are but pocket complements, run 'em over once, and then perhaps I ſhall talke with yee; remember where ye left, I wu'd be loath to put ye out ſir, my haire was golden twiſt, ye ſaid, come, what of all this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This has enflam'd my thoughts,
Enſnar'd my ſoule, and made me vow
A deſperate deſtruction to my ſelfe,
Except from you I have one gracious ſmile
May ſtile me ſervant;
And for your fathers minde,
I know it jumpes with our deſires.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: My fathers minde? dee thinke his froſty beard,
Can temper my affections,
No, no,
His precepts are too wither'd for my youth;
Know ſir,
That I diſdaine thoſe low-borne wormes
That will be circumſcrib'd by dotage
In loves affaires: I ſcorne to be directed,
I am my ſelfe ſir, and my onely ſoule
Is my owne will and humour:
But pray whence come theſe words?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: From my deepe paſſions.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Whence thoſe paſſions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From your faire eyes, they
Were the happie guiders of my ſoule,
Vnto this bower of wonder;
They fir'd my heart
Which burnes, and will doe in remorſleſſe flames,
Vntill from them I doe receive a glance,
May ſweeten theſe my torments.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Not ſo loud I pray you, ſpeake ſoftly ſir. They whisper.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Speake Mirabell,
May I thinke a proud thought.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O by no meanes ſir, they are great ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This of mine's a vertue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What may it be ſir?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Nothing Lady, but a preſumptuous ſtudy to be yours.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, you may ſpeake what you pleaſe, but firſt
Let it arrive my apprehenſion what
Or how you meane, according to my skill,
I will returne my anſwer.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Onely to be
One of the number that doe ſtill attend
Your pleaſures becke, and ſo be ſtil'd your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir,
My thoughts nor fortunes ever were ſo high,
To keepe a ſervant of that conſequence,
And tis my hope they never will, or ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Breake not a ſacred oath, for I have ſworne
My ſelfe your ſervant: then for pitties ſake,
Doe not infringe my vow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well,
Tendring your vow, Suppoſe I ſhud admit
Your ſelfe into my ſervice, wod ye ſtrive,
T' expreſſe the faith and diligence belongs
Vnto a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: My pleaſure and delight ſhud fixe,
On nothing more than to expreſſe,
My faith and loyalty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, I admit you into my ſervice,
But by the way you may perhaps obſerve
Some paſſages betwixt a friend and me,
As letters, tokens paſſages, or ſo;
Which if ye doe, take heede ye word it not,
But ſtill poſſeſſe your ſelfe with ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Betwixt a friend and you? — umph.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ne're ſcratch your head about it, for y' are now My ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I am, I've ſworne it, and I will be ſo,
But yet ye did not heare me ſweare my ſelfe,
A ſervant to your friend — Ile none of that.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Tis love that makes me here preſent my ſelfe,
And with my ſelfe to tender up my ſoule,
Engag'd by vowes and oathes to waite upon
No creature but your ſelfe:
Love is the ſpurre that prickes me on to this,
And love you know can brooke no rivalls.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Doe you love and ſerve your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: You and my ſelfe I doe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Your ſelf's the friend I meane, and this diſcourſe
Has beene a true proſpective glaſſe, whereby
To peepe into your minde, which now I finde
Full fraught with ſweetneſſe, when I did deſire,
Ye wod keepe private what ye did obſerve,
'Twas nothing elſe
But to be ſecret to your ſelfe and me;
Sir, in a word, I doe embrace your love.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Be not too prodigall of thy goodneſſe ſweet,
Conſider what a ſcarciti's of it now
Ith' world.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Let this ſuffice ſir, — I am yours.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray let me intreate ye to love your ſelfe a little better than to ſpend all this breath to no purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Why then Ile take my leave, but firſt, let this ſnow white hand but daine to bleſſe the unhallowed lippes of your admiring Slave, that I may hence with gladneſſe, and have cauſe to boaſt of ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: With all my heart ſir; but I pray how long were you Doctor of the chaire in the ſchoole of complements?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O they can never come from a dejected ſpirit. Kiſſes her hand.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, now I hope you are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wiſh my heart could truely ſpeake it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, come, you are too importunate.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O let not anger bend ſo ſmooth a brow,
Not for the earths hid minerall wod I give
The leaſt occaſion of a frowne to thee,
For if I ſhud,
I ſhould perpetually abhorring my ſelfe
Though not a word,
Yet let me have one glance before I goe,
For nothing faire one ſpeakes a lovers minde,
So well as the eye,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: They talke of women, but you are able to teach all the women in the world to talke much to little purpoſe, for ought I ſee; come I muſt tutor ye a little, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Were I ſo happy to be your Pupill, I were a wonder
to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: If it were ſo I thinke you wod not be much troubled to make him untruſſe forſooth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For pitties ſake jeſt not at pitties object:
Little knoweſt thou the miſeries of him,
That has his amorous flames return'd with ſcorne:
Well, ſince tis thus, I will my ſelfe tranſlate
From this mortality, and embrace my Fate.

div.stage: To them Sir Timothy Teſty, Sir Plenteous Crambagge.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No further, no further, pray returne.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Good ſir give me leave to bring you a little further.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Pray yee, returne, ye doe but trouble your ſelfe and me to no purpoſe, well, Sir Plenteous Crambagge I thanke ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Farwell good ſir Timothy Teſty.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come girles, come— where's Hilts? — ha. Where is he?
Where are you ſir, when ye ſhud waite upon me? —ha, Where I ſay?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I was but ith' cellar, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Ith' cellar forſooth? what buſineſſe have you ith' cellar for ſooth? who ſhud waite upon me the whilſt? wherefore doe I give you three pound a yeare, and a trencher-cloake? — ha? — well—

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Farewell ſir Plenteous,

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Farewell good ſir Timothy Teſty. Exit ſir Tim. cum ſuis. How does my coſin Fairefaith? how ſhall we ſquander away this afternoone, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: As you pleaſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Come, I have a mighty minde to be merry, what ſo ere the matter is.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I'me very glad of it ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: But I have alwayes obſerved that when I am ſo extreamely diſpos'd to mirth, one vexation or other falls preſently in the very nicke.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: It falls ſo ſometimes ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir. P.
sp.l: Well come, what de'e ſay gallants?
My thoughts me thinkes are on a jocond pin,
I am ſtrain'd up to a mightie pleaſant key, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What ſay you coſin Valentine?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: What ye pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Nay, I' me indifferent, my maſters walke the fields.
Goe by Water, ſee a Play, or what ye will, tis
All one to me, come what ſay you ſonne, — ſpeake?
Which of theſe three, come, come, you are too ſad▪
Say, what ſhall wee doe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What yee will ſir, I confeſſe I doe ſometimes Walke the fields, thinking to purge vexatious thoughts, but whereſoever I turne mine eye, ſomething or other miniſters occaſion of freſh tortures: when I go by water, then the waves that tumble one in the others necke, preſent to my fancy the multiplicity of diſtraction crowding in at the doore of my thoughts, and for ſeeing a Play, I confeſſe it a brave thing, both to feaſt the wit, and recreate the minde: but, I thinke I ſhall ere be long ſee my ſelfe act my owne Tragedie.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: I told you coſin, this Sunny flaſh wud have a ſtorme;
Whats the matter ſonne? — ha? —
Why thus dejected? —
Speake—coſin, what is the buſineſſe?
What ayles my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No great hurt ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Speake man, heres none but friends, unbreſt your ſelfe, Whats the matter I ſay?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing ſir, onely a melancholy fit.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Nothing? thats ſtrange—Coſin, how comes my ſonne thus diſcontented? what wud he have?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Sir, to ſtretch your patience no further than it will reach, tis a gentlewoman that hee wud have, a good luſtie hanſome gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: A gentlewoman? how dee meane a gentlewoman? What wud he doe with her coſin?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I cannot tell ſir, he has a uſe for her it ſeemes, hee is in love with her, you may imagine now what hee wud doe with her.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: How? in love with a gentlewoman?
You are a forward boy indeede — I hope
'Tis with one that hath a good portion, if not youth by
Gold and ſilver, you and I ſhall not be friends — umph:
In love quoth a? It is a thing coſen, I never yet knew
What it was, and yet I'me three ſcore and upwards.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Not ſir,
Were ye not in love with your Lady before ye married her?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis true, I had a great deale of money with her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: More than your ſonne's like to have with this gentlewoman I heare.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Say ye ſo? how comes this about ſonne? — ha? Iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Sir,
Tis not this tranſitory pelfe,
Nor all the trumperie the world cries up
That I reſpect; no, I eſteeme a ſoule
Sweetned with education;
Let dung admirers idolize their bagges;
Tis not for man,
In whom there dwells an immortality:
I have made a choice,
Not for ſuch by reſpects, this creature is
The pride and darling both of love and fame:
Sir, know that I
Scorneto diſhonor my good ſtarres ſo farre,
As to beſmeare my ſoule with traſh,
Or to prophane Loves ſacred rites for wealth.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Come, come, tell not me of education, and I cannot tell what, I muſt have money, I cannot purchaſe land
With education not I, neither with all your
Philoſophy, I tell you, I muſt have
Mony, and I will have mony — but prethee coſin what is this
Gentlewoman — ha?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A brave luſty bouncing Laſſe, I can ell ye— what dee thinke of Miſtreſſe Sabina Teſty, daughter to Sir Timothy Teſty.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: She is the goddeſſe of your ſonnes idolatry.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Shee? Paſſion of my heart, ſonne, coud'ſt thou finde no body elſe to dote on but ſhe? did I carke, and care, and watch, and toile and moyle, and ſweate for this — ha? have I endur'd a thouſand millions of curſes for exacting of forfeitted bonds, and morgag'd lands for this? Sir Timothy Testy's daughter, quoth a? a wild ſlut, her father a decai'd gentleman, and one that with riot and exceſſe has cut ſo many collops out of his eſtate, that ſometimes he is glad to keepe his chamber, and gentily begin a courſe of phyſicke two or three yeares together, Sir Timothy Teſty's daughter quoth a?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O my heart, me thinkes it teares in a thouſand ſhivers, Miſtreſſe — father — friends, and all averſe to my deſires, be not ſo cruell Fates.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Well, to be ſhort, if ſir Timothy can, or will, give a conſiderable portion, tis a match, if not, Pardona moy, good ſon, I will not have a brood of beggers in my houſe — not I.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Stay a little ſir, the greateſt matter you doe not either know, or conſider, were your conſent the thing, that I thinke wod not be much ſtood upon; but here comes the breake necke of the buſineſſe; the gentlewoman ſcornes him.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: How? ſcorne the Crambags? Sir, Be it knowne to all men by theſe preſents, that there's ne're a gentleman of 'em all but are now and then glad to be beholden to the Crambagges; ſhe ſcorne him? come coſin, Ile goe talke with her father about it, but firſt Ile know her portion.

div.stage: Exeunt ſir Plen. and Faire.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Tis in vaine, ſhe cannot love, not? why can ſhe not love? am I ſo vile a thing? no, I am not, whats the reaſon then? tis her immortall minde that wings her thoughts above my reach, there, there 'tis; what ſhall I doe then? turne coward and ſuffer it; nay, what can I doe — what? I can die —
sp.l: O ye fields of bliſſe,
If ye containe a flowrie grove of reſt,
Prepar'd for thoſe that muſt needs dye for love,
Embrace my vowes, and entertaine that ſoule
That flies for ſhelter to your ſacred ſhades, Offers to draw.
Come forth thou purge of melancholy,
Rip up this lumpe of ſadneſſe, cut thoſe chaines,
Wherewith my ſoule is linckt to miſerie;
—Stay,—come downe proud thoughts,
Conſider well what ye attempt to doe:
Am I a ſacrifice for ſuch a wight?
— O no, Ile then reſolve to live,
Although it be but to torment my ſelfe,
And thinke that torment pleaſure, cauſe tis ſhee,
For whom alone I ſuffer miſerie.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter ſir Timothy Teſty, ſir Plenteous Crambagge.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: PIſh, pray ſir doe not urge me, I'me a little buſie.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis but a word ſir, and the matter ends.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Words, or matter, I cannot heare it now I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis a concernement requires your ſerious intention, as much as mine ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sir, I doe not uſe to ſtep out of my humour, neither for my owne ſake, nor no mans elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis for your owne profit and good, pray heare it ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, lets here it then, lets heare it, but dee heare, be breefe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Thus it is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Nay, come come, make an end, make an end.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I have not begun yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Preethee make an end I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Well, then you ſhall heare the end: my ſonne Valantine has a minde to make a conjunction copulative with your daughter Sabina.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Speake in a plainer part of ſpeech man, what dee meane?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: He has a minde to lye with her ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Ile ſee him hang'd firſt, except he marry her firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: So he does entend ſir, but you would not heare the beginning, which made me beginne at the end.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, come to th'point, what ſaies my daughter too't?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Rich Parents ne're queſtion that ſir, they firſt wiſely agree upon Portions, ſeale Writings, then marry the young couple, and afterwards, give 'em time to conſider of that, if we may have your conſent, I make no queſtion of hers.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, ye have it, ye have it.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I thanke yee ſir, I ſhall make my ſonne a glad man when I come home ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Send 'em joy, come, is this all ye have to ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis all ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, fare yee well.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Stay ſir, I had like to have forgot the maine buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Puh, yet againe, ſpeake, ſpeake come, what iſt?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I wud deſire to know ſir what bleſſings you meane to beſtow upon your daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Piſh, dee thinke Ile be backward in theſe things? She ſhall have a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Tis a faire portion ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Have ye done now?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: I have done, I have done, heavens protect ye ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A due, a due.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: —Good ſir, but one word more, and then I have done.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What againe, what ailes the man tro?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Onely this ſir, I hope you'le pay the money upon the wedding day ſir, will not ye?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Money? — what money?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The marriage money ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What marriage money?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: The thouſand pound? what dee meane ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Did you not ſay but now you wod give a thouſand pound with her?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I told you I wod give her a thouſand bleſſings; paſſion of my heart, a thouſand pound quoth a? ſir I ſcorne it; ye have abus'd me to thinke ſo, let thoſe ſcraping curmudgions, that for the moſt part beget • riples and idiots like themſelves, I ſay, let thoſe doo't J tell ye; on the wedding day, as I ſaid, Ile give her a thouſand bleſſings with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: And ne're a penny of mony?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What? Not with your owne childe?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Not a Denier, not one Denier:

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Why then give me leave to tell yee, your reſolution is unworthy, nay, tis ſcurvy.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How ſcurvy? and in my owne houſe too?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Ay ſcurvy, and I muſt tell yee, argues no better than a beggerly diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Beggerly diſpoſition? O baſeneſſe it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Baſe, I n'ere ſtood yet ſir with my cap in my hand to a Scrivener for the procuring of ten pounds upon my owne bond.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How? I ſtand with my cap in my hand ye raſcall? when? when? how? to whom? I ſtand with my cap in my hand? — I defie thee. Enter Hilts. I ſtand with my cap in my hand?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: How now? what dee affront my maſter in's owne houſe ſir, pray avoide.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out of my houſe ye dunghill, ye dirt, yee ſpawne of ten ith hundred.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come, come ſir, lets ſee your backe, or your worſhips pate feele the weight of my cudgell.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out ye villaine.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Very well ſir. Exit ſir Plenteous.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A ſlave abuſe me thus, and in my owne houſe too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Come ſir, doe not trouble your ſelfe, he's gone now

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A Sirra, an old Pancridge.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Nay I ſee you are bell mettle ſir if you'r angred once.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Angry? twas well thou cam'ſt in, for in my conſcience I had kill'd the rogue elſe. Enter Sabina, Mirable. Whorſon dogbolt affront me thus.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Whats the matter Hilts, who has vext my father thus

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Old Crambag forſooth, has beene here and ſo abus'd me as I was never abus'd ſince I peept into the world, and whats the reaſon forſooth, becauſe his ſon and heire's in love with you forſooth, and entends to make you his bride forſooth, therefore muſt I give thim a thouſand pound forſooth, but Ile ſee him hang'd for a ſigne ats owne doore firſt; the truth is
daughter, his ſonne is a pretty gentleman, but heres the thing, his ſonne, as I perceive is mad in love, and for ought I ſee, rather than faile, he will give me a thouſand pound for my conſent, were not I an Aſſe then Hilts, to give a man a thouſand pound to marry my daughter; when the ſame man rather than goe without her will give it me? were not I a Buzzard then I ſay?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: A man wod thinke ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Why ſhod I doe it —ha? give me but a why, and I'me ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: In troth ſir I cannot give you any great reaſon, unleſſe your purſe were ſicke of a Plurifie which I cud ne're finde yet.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Well, for the buſineſſe of marriage, uſe your owne minde daughter, I cannot tell, perhaps the old curre may leave him an eſtate — Well, once trouble not me, and doe your pleaſure, but if you talke of money, I ſhall be angry, come along Hilts. Exit ſir T.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: This young gentleman, a nimble ſparke I ſee, that I did not thinke the young co •• wod have beene leaping ſo quickly —therefore doe you hamper him as ſoone as yee can, dee heare.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Come away Hilts.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I'me comming and pleaſe your worſhip. Exit Hil.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Adviſe me in this dangerous maze to ſteere a ſafe courſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yee are in a faire way to doe your ſelfe a great deale of good, keepe your ſelfe in't ſiſter, the gentlemans a great heire, ſweetly behav'd, bravely diſcourſt▪ and beſides, a proper hanſome compleate gentleman, what can you deſire more ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Siſter, I love the gentleman, at firſt, I confeſſe, I did a little ſleight him, but my ſecond thoughts fram'd a recantation which my intentions have directed to ſalute him ſpedily.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A way with it ſiſter, give it not a minuts more entertainement for a world, ſend it immediatly.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, Ile diſpatch it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Be certaine ye doe ſiſter. Exeunt Sab. Mir.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Traſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: —umph,
And was I borne to the ſport of Fate,
Cud not the deſtinies as well have ſaid
Be happy
— inexorable ſtarres,
Had ye but doom'd me to have trod the pathes
Of dreadfull baniſhment never to returne,
T'had beene a heaven in reſpect of this
— But tis in vaine,
Vpon the ſtatutes of the ſtarres to plaine;
I muſt even ruſh upon ſome deſperate death,
And theres an end.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Heaveans forbid ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Theres no remedy, her loves impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Impoſſible? why dee thinke the world containes a creature cannot be won.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Yes indeed?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: You might as well have told mee, that hee that has a Puritanicall wife cannot be a cuckold ſir; take this from me, there's not the braveſt gallant that e're went naked to the middle, but a hanſome man, good cloathes, language, and money will bring her under the ſee, I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Sir, me thinkes it were not a miſſe if you did caſt your eye upon ſome other, the world is wide and populous, and now and then to looke a ſquint, wud be a good way to aſſwage the violence of your paſſion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O no, ſhe—ſhe is the blaſing ſtarre where on I gaze, and the little world of beautie which I admire.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O brave Maſter — there was a ſpeech; O Maſter Sportlove, this learning's a dainty matter — dee heare ſir, ſhall I goe and tell her what ye ſay? —

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: You cannot come againe time enough, let it alone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I warrant ye ſir. Exit Traſh.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, Try her againe ſir, ye cannot tell, droppes of raine may pierce an Adamant.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: That's with often falling upon't ſir, if he cud but learne that, ſhe wud love him preſently.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Puſh, away with theſe fruitleſſe paſſions, be your ſelfe once againe.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: That cannot be ſir, you muſt conſider he is in love.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why, cannot a man be in love, and yet be himſelfe too?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: He may be, but 'tis raro aut nunquam, jealouſie in a woman, love in a man, and tooth ach in a dogge, are three of the moſt dangerous things I can tell ye, that are incident to mortalls. Enter Traſh.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, I'me come againe gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: What already, and done your errand too?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: O rarely, ſir, I had it as perfect —

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Sirra, what did yee tell her? you are ſo officious.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I told her ſir, that your worſhip ſaid, ſhe was the ſtaring blaze whereon you gaz'd, and the world of little beauty which you admir'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Out ye rogue, yee ſmall knowing raſcall, thou haſt undone me; did I tell ye ſo? doſt thou goe and turne my words backwards, ye villaine. Falls upon him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if I cud runne away from him, I wud not be beholden to yee, for ſhame, doe not ſtand ſtill and ſee a man kill'd.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: It was but a miſtake ſir, pray pardon him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Twas nothing ſir, but onely the wrong end came out firſt, the gentlewoman underſtood it well enough.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Come, pray ye ſir have patience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I muſt kill the rogue, for he will never have wit.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Forbid that ſir, if men ſhud be kill'd for want of wit, I had beene a Maſterleſſe coxcombe long agoe ſir, but tis no matter, you may uſe me at your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come, come, all's well, all's well.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I thats true indeede, when I'me beaten once, then all's well ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: But Mr. Sportlove, nothing but this gentlewoman troubles me, that ſhe ſhud be ſo faire, ſo young, ſo hanſome, and yet cannot love — me thinkes 'tis ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: It may be ſhe feedes upon preſerv'd ſnow, which if ſhe doe, ſhe'le ſeldome have a warme thought, I can tell yee,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Nay, her diet's good Ile aſſure yee, for ſhe will conſtantly have a breakefaſt of Oringoes, a dinner of Potatoes, a Sacke poſſet to ſupper, and ſo goes to bed.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: If ſhe feede thus, tis impoſſible for the poore gentlewoman to hold out long.

div.stage: Enter Betty with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Fellow ſervant, how fares our Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ye were told but juſt now, were not yee?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: This Letter was commanded firſt to kiſſe your hand, and then enforme yee.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: To the gentle hand of her deareſt Valentine addreſſe theſe.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: Ʋal. Sir, I hope by this time your good nature has granted a pardon for my ſeeming raſhneſſe, which proceeded not from a minde fraught with diſdaine, but grounded on a reſolution to be your ſervant, th'old man's not yet in bed, but halfe an houres forbearance lockes him up in ſlumber; about which time my ambition is to ſee you at my chamber, where my ſervant ſhall attend to give you acceſſe to,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Now ſir you wud runne into the fire, and drowne your ſelfe, wud ye? what dee thinke of me now ſir, did I not doe my errant bravely ſir, did not I?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Thou haſt done ingeniouſly, and I will ſtudy correſpondent gratitude.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, pray ſir, I had as leefe you did beate me agen, as give me hard words forſooth, I cannot endure 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O how precious are thoſe minuts wherein are wrapt unexpected joyes, ſweete peece of paper; faire was that ſtarre under whoſe influence thou wert made— O this halfe houres forbearance, pardon ſweet heart, paſſion had almoſt made me forget a due reſpect. Kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Pray ſir doe not charge your memory with theſe things, leave 'em to me ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: To you ſir, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Becauſe ſhee is the Sugar-plumme—of my affections ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cry yee mercy, farewell pretty Ducke; tell your Miſtreſſe I will flie like time, till I have bleſt theſe eyes with the ſight of her. Exit Betty.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Coſin, y'are now in a progreſſe towards the gentlewoman, take a little of my advice along with ye — having now the advantage of a faire opportunitie, try her every way, you know my meaning, and then as you finde her diſpos'd, you may better diſpoſe of your affections.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Sir, were it in my caſe, I tell ye in plaine termes, I wud promiſe her a thouſand things, and it may be for a nights lodging, I wud vow'em and ſweare 'em too; but when J had once ſatisfied my purpoſes, I wud ſhew her a faire paire of heeles, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Spoke like a gentleman, Ile aſſure yee ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tis eaſie ſporting where no paine is felt,
Come, come, lets goe.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We attend your pleaſure ſir, for I perceive you long to be where your minde is.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A lacke aday, you muſt conſider ſir every thing wud live.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sweet, I come. Exit Val. Fai.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Didſt ever ſee a paſſion ſo tranſport a man, heaven • bleſſe his wits.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Twas a good prayer ſir, but he muſt have 'em firſt.

div.stage: Exeunt Spo. Traſh.
Enter Sabina, Betty.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What ſaid he Betty when he read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Bett,
sp.p: Hee was ſo raviſht with joy, that J thinke he knew not what hee ſaid forſooth, and for the letter, he did ſo cull it, and lull it, and clip it, and hugge it, and buſſe it—O me Miſtreſſe, this love—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Tis a pretty pleaſant vexation; but did he ſay hee wud come?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
He told me he wud come with all ſpeede, and that hee ſhud thinke every minute a hundred yeares till hee ſaw yee, with many other pretty words which I cannot repeate
for ſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I ſhall be extreame melancholy till I ſee him; but are you ſure he did ſay he wud come?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Very certaine, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: How long dee thinke it will be firſt?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Your owne appointment was halfe an houre, but for ought I ſaw, he was reſolv'd not to forbeare ſo long forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Prethee Betty helpe me to coſen the time a little with ſome pretty love Song.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That will but make yee the more melancholy forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Though it doe, yet me thinkes I love it dearely.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Me thought yee ſaid ye were afraid of being melancholy but now forſooth?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I did ſo, and ſo I am, and yet I love it.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I had heard 'em ſay forſooth, that melancholy people are like Spaniells.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Bets.
sp.p: They ſay a Spaniell, the more a man beates him the more he fawnes upon him; ſo melancholy people, me thinkes, the more the humor torments 'em the more they love it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Tis very true, come reach me my Lute— prethee ſing Betty.

div.head: A Song.
div.l: BE not ſo cruell faireſt Boy,
But unſtring thy golden bow,
In love we muſt expect no joy,
Nothing there but ſorrow's flow;
If thy flaming arrow did
But touch, yet it ſtill appeares,
We muſt for ever after bid
Farewell joye, and welcome teares;
Tell us, then tell us where doth grow,
The herbe that cures the wounded eye,
Elſe we muſt cry alas and woe,
There's no ſuch herbe that growes, and dye.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Twas well ſung.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
No indeede forſooth my voyce is quite gone, Chambermaides have occaſion you know forſooth now and then to
ſit up in the nights when they have buſineſſe to doe, and that ſpoiles a maids voyce quickly forſooth —they knocke.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: They're come I vow, runne to the doore.

div.stage: She runnes to doore and lets them in.
Enter Ʋalentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Traſh the three Gentlemen ſalute Sabina.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: My little Tewxbury muſtard, how does thou doe?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Muſtard? why muſtard, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Becauſe I never come neere thee, but thou makes my very eyes water.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Sir, tis fit wee now withdraw; the darkeneſſe of the night preſwaded our attendance, now common civilitie requires our abſence—pleaſures attend your proceedings ſir.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Sweet night embrace ye ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Thankes noble ſir, peace conduct ye.

div.stage: Exeunt Fair. Sport. Betty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Well now your worſhips pleas'd I hope —but ſtay, Where's Betty?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She's gone out with the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Gone out with the gentlemen quoth a? and I ſtand here.

div.stage: Exit Traſh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your courteous invitation makes ſome recompence for the late ſcorne with which you did ſlight my honeſt zeale.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I doe acknowledge ſir
The error of my raſhneſſe, and begge pardon,
I have inform'd my judgement better ſince;
And you appeare to my opinion
More acceptable farre than when you firſt
Preſented your deſires with your ſelfe,
That now ſhall want no fitting entertainement
To ſatisfie the firſt neglect.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: I cannot deny, but that it made 〈…〉
Of ſome ſad thoughts within me, but I 〈…〉
A little rectified, conſideration
Hath almoſt cur'd my paſſions, and my fire
Of love is ſome what abated.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: The few houres
Are added to my age, ſince you laſt ſaw me,
Have made no wrinkles yet upon that beauty,
To which you then did give large attributes,
And to be cold ſo ſoone, argues 'twas onely
Your flattery and courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not ſo Lady,
I ne're diſſembled any falſe intents,
My words were the true characters of my thoughts,
Onely your ſcorne, —there tis.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sir I amalter'd much
From that bad humor, and my heart hath tane
A flame into it from the obſervation
Of your compleate deſervings, and is ready
To anſwer your deſires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You engage me
To a due gratitude, but I have ſetled
New reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sir, ye are now revengefull,
And puniſh ſcorne with ſcorne; a gentle nature
Wud not deny a reconciliation
Vpon ſuch tearmes; but you ſuſpect my freeneſſe.
I bluſh to thinke on't, and am ſorry ſir,
The offer of my ſelfe is no more valued,
Than thus to be refus'd, ſtreight my ſervant
Shall be your guide, and ſo I wiſh ſweete peace
To your faire thoughts. She offers to goe, he brings her backe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They are the fairer, Lady,
In that they have called backe your faireſt ſelfe
To be their object.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Call not backe your humour
To flatter me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By my beſt hopes I doe not;
A Saints devotion 〈…〉 earneſter,

Or more free fro •
• ny pocriſie than my love:
I owne not a deſire but what is yours;
And if agen you chide my forward zeale,
My danger will be more in the relapſe,
Than in the firſt diſeaſe which you have cur'd;
In ſteed of healing Balmes, apply no Corraſives
To my ſicke heart, but gently entertaine
My ſecond motions, for next to Eternitie
You are my happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: You did intimate
That you had fixt upon ſome other beauty,
From whoſe pure excellence, a brighter flame
Is ſhot, than my dull eyes can ſparkle forth;
If it be ſo I ſhall not envy it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your error
Was a juſt motive I confeſſe, but when
I ſaid I had ſetl'd new reſolutions,
I did but diſſemble, which pray pardon firſt,
And then receive me to your faire opinion,
By all the ſacred powers, religious mortalls
Invoke to make an oath of power to force
Beleefe, you onely muſt be ſhe,
Or none; in whoſe bleſt union I ſhall joy,
And ſatisfie my kinreds expectation
Of iſſue.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Urge no more,
My Faith takes all for truth, and in exchange
Of your deare ſelfe, delivers up my ſelfe as freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This bleſt minute doth deſerve
A note in times large regiſter.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: To morrow
Let it have publike motion 'fore our friends;
And when you pleaſe the conſummation
Of our full joyes ſhall follow: Deare, farewell,
I muſt to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will goe with ye ſweet —

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Forbid ye chaſt directors of my ſoule,
Deſire ſhud be ſo forward ere the Ceremonies
Confirme it lawfull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why ſhud we be nice,
And ſtand upon the outſide of our actions
More than the ſubſtance, though we ſhud anticipate
Thoſe pleaſures, ſince our vowes are paſt we neede not
Have ſcruple, they'le beget a ſecond doubt,
And make the earneſtneſſe of love ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: O fie upon't ſir, doe not cloud your vertue
With ſuch a ſtaine, y'are lovely to me yet,
And ſhall be whilſt y'are faithfull — Ile to bed
And wiſh you reſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Are ye a man?
And wud not take
A better leave of me? Exit Sabina looking backe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How looking backe, and leaving ope the doore,
Ile leave you ſuch an earneſt, if I can
Prevaile, that you ſhall ſweare I am a man.

div.stage: Exit after her.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Fairefaith, Sportlove, and Traſh.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: MY coſin Valentine not yet return'd, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Not yet indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What dee thinke ſhud be the reaſon?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Tis not reveal'd to me ſir; but I thinke hee prevail'd with his Miſtreſſe for a nights lodging, and that may be the cauſe of his long ſtay.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: He has ſtaid ſomething long indeede, but —I beleeve he will come home very ſhortly forſooth.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I confeſſe I long to be acquainted with the iſſue of his enterpriſe.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Betty, Traſh runnes to him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Oh my ſweete Maſter's come agen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am ſo.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And you are even as welcome ſir, as ever poore Maſter was to a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: —Pray ſweete heart returne, let not me trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
No trouble ſir, — if you have any other commands
T' impoſe, I ſhall joy t'obſerve'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I ſweete heart, onely fare ye well. Exit Betty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O my ſweete hony-ſuckle, art thou gone already.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good ſtarres, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Faire morning to my ſweete coſin, we hope health betides your Miſtreſſe, and doe now expect to be gladded with the newes of a faire progreſſe to the end of your deſires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The end of my deſires is even the deſire of my end, for I have no joy on earth.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What agen in theſe perplexities, whence come theſe clouds of diſcontent now? — ye tooke no joy before becauſe ye had no hope t'enjoy her, in whom ye had plac'd all your hopes and joyes, the cauſe of that diſtempers remov'd, what may occaſion this — heavens know.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Ye cannot tell ſir, perhaps the letter was diſſembl'd, and ſhe in ſome idle humor might ſend for him to abuſe him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O coſin Fairefaith, this gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What? cannot ſhe love yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes — love? O yes.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Whence riſe theſe diſtractions then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Even from her love.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: How? can neither frownes nor ſmiles give ye ſatiſfaction, tis ſome what ſtrange, two meere contraries ſhud produce the very ſame effect.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She has with love undone her ſelfe and me.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: There's ſome myſterie in't without queſtion.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I pray ſir untie theſe knotty expreſſions, for I cannot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To be too prodigall of that, which once loſt, the whole world cannot recover — weakeneſſe intolerable Admit Iurg'd her,
sp.l: I'de thought the treaſures not of earth or ſea
Cud have perſwaded ſuch a brave borne minde,
Vnto the pleaſures of forbidden ſheets.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: O ſir, is the winde in that corner now?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: What dee thinke of my opinion now ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O coſin Fairefaith, had I beene a woman —

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You wud have beene an arrant whore in my conſcience. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſay, if I had beene a woman coſin,
Armies of Virgine reſolutions ſhud
Have ſtill environd me:
O miſery!
Had ſhe beene cautious in preſerving that,
That rien of immortality her honor;
Earth had not carried ſuch a Paragon;
But now
Her outward frame ſets but the blacker dye
Vpon her mindes deformity; I'me now reſolv'd
To hate thoſe very thoughts that pitch upon
So pure a peece of impurity.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Puh, what needes all this ſtirre Maſter, ſuppoſe yee have found her to want a graine or two, doe but conſider of it, 'tis nothing amongſt friends; alacke a day ſir, the Goldſmith himſelfe may be coſen'd with a light peece, ant ſhall pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: But will not ye viſit her againe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Never — never.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Nor ſend to her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, neither my ſelfe, nor any one depends on me ſhall ere come there againe.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O poore Betty, I ſhall ne're ſee thee againe, I perceive that.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Come coſin, I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, I ſhall intreate to be excus'd,
I have engag'd my ſelfe to meete a friend,
Which will expect me here immediatly.
Farewell coſin. Exeunt Val. Sport. Traſh.

div.stage: Traſh turne, agen

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Dee heare ſir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Come, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I have a ſtrange thing come juſt now into my head ſir, and that's this ſir; there's Newgate for Theeves, Bridewell for Whores, and Bedlam for Madfolkes, yet among all theſe I doe wonder there's ne're a place for fooles.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p:
'Twere a charitable foundation had a man meanes to doo't with, your Maſter has an eſtate, and might doe well to
thinke of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ye ſay right ſir indeede; charitie ſhud begin at home, that's the truth on't—but let me tell yee ſir, this gentlewoman does a little trouble my ſcull for all that.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What a capcaſe were I in, if her ſiſter ſhud be of the ſame ſtampe, what wud the world ſay, what wud men thinke?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What? — they wud thinke ye were borne when the ſigne was either in Aries, Taurus, or Capricorne, that's all they wud thinke for ought I know, and ſo fare yee well. Exit Traſh.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Children and fooles tell truth, well
If't be my fate, there's no remedy,
Nor friend to flie unto in ſuch a caſe
But honeſt patience. Enter Mirabell.
Stay, here ſhe comes, Ile ſee,
If in her carriage I can reade my fortune
— What my Mirabell—unexpected happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How dee ſir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Better then I was.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why? were ye ſicke ſir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Suppoſe I had beene, or am, your preſence wud beget a health immediatly, J confeſſe I was not even now ſo well as now I am, becauſe I wanted thee which now I have ſweeteſt.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I ſhud be loth to be found wanting, when your occaſions call upon my ſervice ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sweetly ſpoken faire Mirabell,
But heare me,
Admit I had a ſtrange occaſion now
To try thy boſome, wudſt thou be content
To runne a hazard that might manifeſt
Thy love and loyalty?

sp.speaker: Mir
sp.l: There's not a danger in the world can be
So dreadfull to my thoughts, but I wud runne
T'embrace it for the pleaſure of my love;
But pray ſir, what meane theſe doubts?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Nothing faire one, onely a conceit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: May it concerne me ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Yes —'tis but a thing incident to all your Sexe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pleaſe you t' unlocke your minde ſir,
Ile ſtudy what I can to purge your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Tis onely this —I feare you are too coy,
That's all my feare, too coy Mirabell, too coy,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Coineſſe! O heavens! tis the only object of my ſcorne s;ir,
I doe not thinke there's ſuch a thing ith' world,
Or that kinde nature
Was e're the mother of ſo vile a monſter;
Were I perſwaded that my veines contain'd,
But the leaſt dramme of ſuch a peeviſh humor,
Though't kept my heart alive Ide rince it out;
In a word I diſdaine it.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: My hopes ſay you doe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, if you pleaſe,
Put your invention to the racke,
Till it finde out ſome ſtrange device to try
Whether I'me coy or no;
Breath but a ſyllable, and it ſtraight commands
The mind or perſon to ſerve
Your pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: There's not a tittle of a word in this,
But has its quire of harmony;
But why doe I deferre ſo great a bliſſe?
Come, let love embraces crowne our ſweete deſires.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What dee meane ſir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Onely a gentle taſte of loves delicious ſweets.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What, before we marry?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your reaſon.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: O it puts life into a patient expectation — come.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pray forbeare ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: How? forbeare?
What's become of this preſent minuts proteſtations.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I never dream'd that you
Had ever ſullied your well tutor'd ſoule
With ſuch a vile intention.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Come, come, where twining hearts unite
What neede theſe ſcruples?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir,
Staine not your breſt with ſuch ignoble thoughts,
Tis true —
I ſcorne proud coineſſe, but I doe abhorre
To thinke of this.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: O that thoſe eyes
Shud be the portalls to a heart of flint,
I cannot endure it;
Come, come, I muſt needs ſatisfie my flames.
Therefore no more excuſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, ye have uttr'd words
Doe breath an aire wud kill a Baſiliske;
Call yee this love?
'Tis rather treaſon 'gainſt Loves Majeſtie▪
Will you pretend t'expreſſe a love to me,
And yet ſpeake ruine to my reputation;
Baniſh theſe thoughts, or elſe for ever be
A deteſtation to my boſome.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Dwell in thy goodneſſe, gentle love;
'Twas not to pleaſe a wanton appetite,
Or ſpot thy ſhrine of Virgine puritie
That I have ſpoke;
No it was onely but to trie the ſtrength
Of thy reſolves in goodneſſe, what before
I did but love, I now admire;
But—
If like thy ſiſter thou hadſt ſwarv'd a jot,
From that integritie wherewith I ſee
Thy minde is fortified, I ſhud have cut
Thee off from my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How's this? if like my ſiſter, ſay ye?
What has ſhe done, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: No great hurt forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If ye love me tell me ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p:
Now ye conjure me, I will. My coſin Ʋalentine Crambagge that was ſo in love with her, it ſeemes he prevail'd with her a little too much, to give it ye
in plaine termes he has lyen with her, glutted himſelfe with the ſweet ſpoiles of her virginity, and now for ought I heare by the vertue of Hocus Pocus, my gentlemans gone.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Accurſed fate, Sabina thus diſhonor'd,
And by thy kinſman?
I feare too much of that deteſted blood
Flowes in thy veines, henceforth Ile not converſe
Either wirh thee or any other man
That is of kindred to him, pray ye be gon,
Your preſence turnes my very ſtomacke up,
Take't as ye pleaſe, I muſt for e're diſcard ye.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Diſpleas'd with me for his faults?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Tis all one, ſpeake not —reply not—your ſentence Is this —fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: I obey it — Exit Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It has beene ſtill obſerv'd ſince time begun
That ſweeteſt natures ſtill are ſooneſt wonne,
This is the fate that uſually attends
Beſt diſpoſitions:
Poore women! into how many fooles paridices are wee daily brought by theſe wicked men!
Ah poore ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How now, what ayles your ſiſter now?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nothing forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What does the wedding hold or no? —ha?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Shees wedded already ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How? and I not know on't? what a forward ſawcy girle's this?
But is ſhe married indeede?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, to miſery, ſhame, and infamy.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What's the matter girle? — ha? — ſpeake — what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hee that pretended ſo much love to her, I meane young Crambragge.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Ay —what of him? —ha? what's the buſineſſe I ſay?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O Siſter, ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Daughter, I charge ye tell me what the matter is,
what of young Crambagge?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: He — that villaine has by ſmooth words wrought upon her gentle nature, to her perpetuall diſhonor; to tell ye the plaine truth ſir, he has lyen with her, publiſh'd it abroad to her diſgrace, and is now fled.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: —umph — lyen with her? — and fled?
Is there no thunder left above the skye?
Is Iove growne deafe? or has he ſworne to lie
A ſleepe, and thus forget the earth? Enter Traſh.
What's your buſineſſe ſirra?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Sir, my Maſter ſent me to your worſhip, to tell your worſhip, that your worſhip needs not trouble your ſelfe about your daughters portion, for his mindes alter'd, and hee bid tell your worſhip that he wud intreate your worſhip to have patience.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sirra, your Maſter's a raſcall, and you are another.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O by no meanes, and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: O Mirabell, me thought I had a good opinion of him, he had ſo civiliz'd her, and me thought had brought her to be the beſt natur'd girle:
sp.l: Mercileſſe fate,
My paſſive fortitude wherewith I once
Out-fac'd misfortune now is fled and gone,
My daughter thus digrac'd?
What's the reaſon I knew't no ſooner?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It comes too ſoone whenſoever ſir;
The meſſenger has heeles of lead that brings
Good newes, but ill newes flye with Eagles wings.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Stand faſt ye weake ſupporters of my age
Henceforth my hand be pillow to my head,
O my perplexed ſoule!
Cud I but leape now from ſome rockie top,
Into the plunging ſwallow of the ſea,
'Twud be ſome eaſe,
Fetch her Mirabell, fetch her, Exit Mirabell.
Alas I little dream'd of this.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Your worſhip might have dream'd on't, for to my knowledge your worſhip was a ſleepe in your bed when the
buſineſſe was done.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O that I had the rogue by the eares.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I but he does not deſire to give eare to yee.

div.stage: Enter Mirabell, with Sabina very penſive

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out ye ſtrumpet, ye whore, does thou play the whore and looke me in the face? haſt thou playd the baggage? haſt thou playd the whore? — Ha? Out of my ſight ye queane, get ye out. Exit Sabina.

O Mirabell is there no ſtones, nor water, fire nor ſword to be revenged with — Ha? Enter Hilts. Come Sir, you keepe a fine order here, I appoint you to over ſee my houſe, and you let gentlemen come in and lye revelling here all the night, you are a truſty Trojan you.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Tis more then I know Sir, tis the firſt time I heard on't, if I had ſeene the ſawcy raſcalls I wud have ſent 'em further with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Abominable — thus to diſgrace her ſelfe and me, where is ſhe, did not I bid ye fetch her?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She has beene here Sir, and you ſent her out againe.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Has ſhee? I know not, theſe diſtractions do ſo confound me, that I forget the laſt minute: O daughter Mirabell what ſhud I doe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Me thinkes your worſhip ſhud keepe alwayes a rope about your houſe againſt ſuch a deſperate caſe as this is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Hilts take that rogue, and dee heare, deliver him from me to the keeper of Bridewell — take him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come Sir come, are ye come hither to jeere?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No Sir, I did not jeere Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Take him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come along come.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Maſter Hilts, your maſter does but jeſt man.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sir your maſter has abuſd my houſe, and Ile make him ſmart fort.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Tis like enough and pleaſe your worſhip, but ſhall I be puniſht for the wickedneſſe of my Maſters Codpeece, and pleaſe your worſhip, no no.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Carry him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your worſhip's a merry Gentleman, you love to make ſport I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Hilts, I bid you once more carry him away, what dee thinke to laugh me out of my reſolutions?

sp.speaker: Hilts,
sp.p: Come your wayes ſirra.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hilts is in ſober ſadneſſe and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: So am I too ſirra, carry him I ſay —

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Was thou mad to talke thus to a Iuſtice of Peace, a Iuſtice of Corum horum rotulorum? 'tis as much as thy life's worth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A prating ſawcy raſcall; carry him away.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I beſeech your worſhip forgive me, good your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Carry him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Good your worſhip forgive me, I beſeech your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, let him goe for this time, get ye gone ſirra.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes and ſhall pleaſe your worſhip — gone quoth a? Ile ſee your worſhip hang'd before Ile come neere ye againe.

div.stage: Exit Traſh.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O Hilts, this wicked fellow has undone us.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Who dee meane ſir? Mr. Crambagge?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: What has he done ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What? my cheeks wud burne to ſpeake it, uncontrouleable fates — is there no pitty in your votes.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.l: Well, if I once meete with him —

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I'de make him an example to all the young lads in England, I wud fuſtinado the carkaſſe of him till the limbs of the rogue flew one from another, and then I wud beate 'em together againe.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No, no, if we ſhud hurt him Hilts, the Law wud be of his ſide.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Hurt him, no forſooth, I wud onely beſtow a little timber upon the ſhoulders of him.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Piſh, piſh, come, goe your wayes to my coſin Muchcraft the Atturney, tell him I'me comming to him for
his advice; in the meane time doe you put the Caſe to him for comming into the houſe at an unſeaſonable time of the night, goe your wayes, Ile be with ye preſently.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Tim. and Mir. at one doore, Hilts at another.
Enter Ʋalentine and Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Your father's comming after us here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where is he? Enter Sir Plent.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O ſonne—I have beene ſo abus'd—nay, and a hundred to one but I had beene ſoundly baſted too, and all this to pleaſe thee.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: As how pray ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I went to treat with ſir Timothy about the marriage, and becauſe I ſtood upon a portion, old Teſty was pleas'd to call me a thouſand raſcalls; and in the heate of the buſineſſe (O my armes!) comes me in that ſame great horſe-bon'd Hilts, and ſo ſhakes me; well ſonne, Ile even walke in, if any body come to pay money tell 'em I'me within, if they come for money, tell 'em I'me not well, for this fellow has ſo bruis'd my armes that I'me not able to tell it; dee heare what I ſay, to ye ſonne? Exit Ʋalentine ſaying nothing as diſpleas'd. Nay lowre and pout till Doomſday, tis all one, I will have money before I give my conſent, come, come, tell mee no more tales—love quoth a? If I had married for love coſin, I had beene a rogue, a foole, a begger; no, no ſonne, I muſt have money, and I will have mony.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Sir, the laſt night your ſonne went to ſee his Miſtreſſe, and prevail'd ſo farre with her, that to tell you the naked truth, they lay together all night; he perceiving her ſo eaſily wonne to wantonneſſe, and fearing hereafter ſhe might be a little too liberall of her entertainement, has caſt her quite off now feares your diſpleaſure for his too much forwardneſſe, and that's the cauſe of his ſadneſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: How? lay with her—'tis not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Not for a gentleman to lie with a hanſome wench, why, 'tis one of the poſſibleſt things that can be ſir.

sp.speaker: Sio P.
sp.p:
I'ame ſorry to heare it coſin, but I'me glad hee has put her off, a company of raſcalls, they are ſerv'd well enough,
I warrant ye, the poore boy hearing how her father had abus'd me, cud not finde in's heart to love her a jot longer; yet for all that coſin, I like not's humor in this, that he cannot talke with a woman but he muſt be jobbing preſently, I doe not like that I muſt tell ye — well 'tis done and paſt now.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I but I'me afraid you'le heare on't again, ſir Timothy intends to clap him up till he has made ſatisfaction, but pray ſir voyce it not that I told ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Will he ſo? tell him, Ile ſee him hang'd by the necke in the high way to Paddington firſt; he clap him up? he ſhall not have ſo much as a haire of his head except it were to choak himſelfe with, and yet my ſonne ſhall goe up and downe, aye, and job him upon the noſe too and hee ſhall not know him; and if you pleaſe tell him, that I'me reſolv'd before I have done with him, ſo bitterly to vexe him, that he ſhall be glad to come with a rope in's hand, and make a humble petition to the Hingman, that he may have lycence to hang himſelfe to ſave his cloathes — come along. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mirabell, Kate.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not vexe?
Why? Doe you thinke there is a woman lives.
That has a ſiſter abus'd as mine
And not yet be vext? To them Fairefaith.
To bring a maid into this miſery,
And all under loves pretence:
This is your kinſman ſir, your owne fleſh and blood ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: The more ſorry am I forſooth;
But if you'le pleaſe to entertaine my vowes,
Of reall love and ſervice once againe
Into your better thoughts, Ile uſe a meanes
That ſhall preſerve her honour from the duſt,
If not abhorre me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let your heart and tongue but correſpond
And you enſlave my ſoule.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: I have already hammer'd in my ſcull,
A vindication that ſhall make her name
Shine to poſteritie.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The boundleſſe Ocean of your goodneſſe drownes
The ſlendernite of what I can returne.
Here ſhe comes, if ye can doe her a favour,
Both ſhe and I will be glad to ſnatch all
Opportunities to expreſſe our thankefull minds ſir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Ladies, thus it is, hee has diſguis'd himſelfe, goes in womans apparell, if ye pleaſe Ile bring ye to him, where, if there be occaſion, you ſhall command my beſt aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pray ye ſir where is the place?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: It is at A Shoomakers houſe in the Strand, but that's all one, follow me. Exeunt Omnes.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Have ye drawne William Woodcocks plea to Triſtram Widgroms declaration — ha?

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: No ſir, the cauſe is remov'd, Woodcocke fearing to be overthrowne at Common Law, comes with a pittifull long bill, makes a caſe of conſcience on't, and ſo is flowne away.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Is he ſo? if I had knowne that Budget, I wud have Pluckt his feathers a little firſt, but 'tis no matter, let him goe. Enter Hilts legging and ſcraping. What's your errand fellow?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Fellow? Sir I'me none of your fellowes, not I.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I beleeve ye are not, whats your buſineſſe before me?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Sir I doe not come to doe my buſineſſe before you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What meane theſe frivolous anſwers? Whoſe man are ye ſir?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: My maſters ſir.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Very good — what mad man are you pray?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Mad ſir, no more than your ſelfe—mad ſir? —umph.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay let him alone Budget, wee ſhall have a brave action of battery here by and by.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Sir, I belong to the right worſhipfull Sir Timothy Teſty; my maſter ſent me for your Vice, the Caſe is this; a Gentleman comes into my maſters houſe at an unreaſonable time of the night contrary to my Maſters knowne will and command, whether is this a treſpaſſe or no?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
No, no, prethee doe not trouble me, I'me a little
buſie. Enter ſir Tim.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Coſin Muchcraft, how dee ſir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir Timothy Teſty, you are kindely welcome ſir, how dee ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Never worſe coſin, — even almoſt dead with griefe, moſt abominably abus'd.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Wherein, pray ye ſir? Gives him a fee.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That I will tell more at large hereafter ſir, not onely a peece, but my whole love attends ye ſir — the caſe is this; a Gentleman comes into my houſe, at an uncivill and unſeaſonable time of the night, contrary to my knowne will and command; a Treſpaſſe or no?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A treſpaſſe: a tranſcedent crime ſir; a moſt foule matter, Ile aſſure ye; your man did not put the Caſe to mee in this manner.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Not? ye whoreſon blockhead, are yee not able to ſpeake to a man? wherefore doe I keepe ye? —ha?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I cud not, I had not inſtructions in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: 'Tis well enough ſir, both Law and Equitie ſupports your cauſe; come, wee'le walke out and talke of it.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Your tongue drops honey coſin, and you have revived my ſtaggering ſpirits:
sp.l: And now though time and age,
Cover my head with honorable haires,
Yet —
Since raies of Sunny thoughts peepe out agen,
Ile ſtrive to quell theſe paſſions — come
Sad ſighes, and teares are Oratours of griefe,
But 'tis an active braine that brings releeſe. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Fairefaith, Sabina in mans apparell, Sportlove, Traſh, and Hilts.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come, pray ſir doe not thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How ſhall I ſtand by and ſee.
A gentlewoman of my kindred wrong'd?
Be patient?
And my kinred thus abus'd? my proper fleſh
And blood diſgrac'd, our reputation turn'd
Quite topſie turvie, nay, and all this done
By a laſcivious villaine?
No, no,
Nothing but's blood ſhall pacifie my ſword;
Had but the ſlave as many thouſand lives
As there doe graines of ſand ſurround the ſea,
There wud be ſcope to vent my fury on;
But now 'tis circumſcrib'd within the verge
Of one poore raſcalls life, whoſe blood will ſcarce
Give ſatisfaction to my thirſty ſteele:
Come ſir, I doe perceive you know his haunts,
which if ye doe,
I doe conjure ye here to bring him forth;
And if you will, or dare to ſecond him,
Ile ſtand ye both.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, on my life I vow,
The place of his abodes unknowne to me;
They ſay he's fled and gone:
Tis true, I had
Some converſation with him, but I was
A ſtranger to his thoughts and actions;
And where this time hee does beſtow himſelfe
Tis not knowne to me.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Sirra, what ſay you? where's your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ah, I wud I cud tell ye, he has left me in a pittifull caſe here, if old ſir Plenteous doe not take pitty upon me, I muſt even go and drive Wheele-barrowes in Lincolnes-Inne-fields, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Alas poore fellow, I'me ſorry for that, what canſt doe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I have a qualitie ſir, but the world now adayes does not reſpect men of parts.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What iſt?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A Bagge-piper, an't ſhall pleaſe your worſhip,

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: A Bagpiper?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes indeede ſir, as ſimple as I ſtand here, I have plaid before as good Beares as be in the Kingdome of England.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Where doſt live now?

div.stage: Enter Ʋalentine in womens apparrell.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Sir, in the meane time J waite upon the Lady that lies in the houſe here.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Come ye hither.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Vnhappy eyes ye have undone my heart.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I come forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Stay faire one, ſtay,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Speake ye to me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I doe,
But firſt, I doe intreate you will be pleas'd
To ſmile upon my raſhneſſe, then muſt I
Perforce enforme ye, that juſt now I felt
A blow upon my heart, which I conceive
Was darted from your eyes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your conceit was in an error ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: O no,
I ſee betwixt thoſe breſts
Is Adons garden, and Eliſiums love, Kiſſes her,
And from theſe lippes proceedes an ayre tranſcends
Sabean ſpices, or the Phoenix neſt;
Lady,
Be pleaſed to let this Jewell pride it ſelfe
Betweene thoſe ſnowie hills, and you engage
My ſoule unto your ſelfe. Gives her a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My gratitude entertaines your loving directions ſir, A word ſir, Valen▪ and Sport▪ goe aſide. What gentleman is this? me thinkes he much reſembles Sabina Teſty, know ye him not?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Not I, I met him here by chance, it matters not who 'tis, take you his gifts —and be ſure to yeeld what hee would have yee doe, and wee ſhall want neither gold nor jewels, I ſee that: and dee heare, you will by this meanes put ſuch a tricke upon your ſweete-hearts Champion as never was,—and in the iſſue it will be found to be but a jeſt, there's and end.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray accept of this.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I were to blame if I ſhud not ſir; Wheelebarrowes, quoth a? Ile ſee 'em all hang'd firſt, a hanſome gentlewomans ſervice is as good as fee taile, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Me thinkes Lady, you much reſemble a gentleman I know, one Mr. Valentine Crambagge, one that I wud be every glad to ſee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know the gentleman ſir, he is, I take it, a friend to one Miſtreſſe Sabina Teſty.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: A friend,
Had ſhe beene dead when firſt ſhe ſaw his face,
She had beene happy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray you why ſir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Has done her that diſhonor,
That time can never raze out of memory;
And in regard ſhe is my neereſt coſin,
The ſad remembrance of it teares my heart
Into a thouſand ſhivers;
But now your preſence like the morning Sunne
Drives off theſe melancholy miſts wherein
My ſoule did ſometimes wander.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: O the ſweetneſſe of thoſe words!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, there's a pound of Sugar almoſt in every word ſhe ſpeakes ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Lets mixe our ſelves.
But firſt, let Hymen with a wedding knot
Knit up our ſoules.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: O no ſir.
