sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay you are now my captive.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall eaſily procure my redemption.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Thy very hearts thy ranſome, nothing ſhall,
But onely that redeeme thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doubt not ſir, but your owne goodneſſe will plead my excuſe;
For know, I did
Set up a reſolution long agoe,
Never to marry.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: How, not marry?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Remember what I told you coſin; Sir, I know ſhee will be perſwaded, but that gentlewomen, yee know, thinke it a kinde of diſparagement to be too ſoone wone, that's all ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray expreſſe your intentions Lady.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: I have already ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: And is that your reſolution?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Indeede it is ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why then Ile tell yee mine:
I'me now in queſt of this deteſted ſlave
That wrong'd my coſin, and doe hope ere long
To vindicate her quarrell, therefore know,
If thou'lt not marry me immediatly,
Thoſe lookes that doe ſo much reſemble his,
Shall whet my ſword againſt thee, nay, convert
My love to fury, and ſhall ſacrifice
Thy blood, to expiat my kindreds wrong;
Therefore I muſt, nay more, I will enjoy;
Deſpight of fate I will;
My quike deſires doe chide my patience,
And thou muſt yeeld or die, than quickly ſpeake;
I cannot ſtand to waite upon diſcourſe:
But by the way conſider, that ye are now
To give a ſentence either of life or death,
Vpon your ſelfe, take heede; if ye ſay aye,
You live my darling, but if no, you die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I conſent to marry, and am content to be diſpos'd of as you ſhall pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Your breath is muſicke now, come lets along.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why, but ſir, you will not carry away my Miſtreſſe I hope in this manner, will ye? and I have but newly got her neither — ſlid, theſe are tricks indeede?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Sirra, there's for you hold you, your peace, it is my humor. Gives him money.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Bleſſe your worſhip ſir, and keepe ye in this humor ſtill ſay I. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter ſir Plenteous, Muchcraft, Budget.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
Well ſir, I heare ye, but yee have not ſpoke toth
purpoſe yet.

sp.speaker: Sir P▪
sp.p: Accept this from me ſir, Ile proove ſir, that my ſonne was invited and ſent for, and that her maide and ſhe both us'd all meanes poſſible to allure him thither. Gives him a fee.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ay, now you have ſpoke home ſir, this is ſomething now, I feele your cauſe a little better▪ and thus much for your comfort, never trouble your ſelfe Enter ſir Timothy ſtanding privately to heare the paſſages, chaſing and ſtamping. about it, Ile take ſuch a courſe that his cauſe ſhall ne're proceed Ile warrant yee, alas ſir Timothy's cauſe is not worth the legge of a Fly, and yet he does ſo torment my houſe, that I can neither eate, drinke, nor ſleepe; yee know Budget how often I have deſir'd him to forbeare my houſe▪ and yet all will not doe.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: I wiſh hee were hang'd, he makes me tell a hundred lies in a weeke in telling him ye are not within, of purpoſe to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Here's a rogue.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Alaſſe for's buſineſſe, were my caſe, if any body wud but give me a ſawcer of Muſtard ſor't, he ſhud have it.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sawcy raſcall.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Suppoſe he brings his action, what can he doe in▪t? — not this, tis true, he wud have retain'd me to have taken out a Writ againſt ye, but when I perceived that it was nothing but a malicious humor, I bid him goe and be hang'd with this brabbles▪ I wud not be troubled with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ T.
sp.p: Very good, but you were willing enough to be troubled with my money, I have heard you all this while, and this your ſucking knave too.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, come, come, Ime glad you are come, Ime glad you are here with all my heart, come, I muſt have you made friends by all meanes.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Friends? Ile ſee him ſtand bare to the taile of a Cart firſt, I friends with him? —hang him raſcall.

sp.speaker: Sir. P,
sp.p:
Sir, I make no doubt but I ſhall make you know, and your daughter too before I have done with her, that ſhee has abus'd my ſonne, I cannot tell, I will not ſay ſhe has bewitch'd him, but if I prove it, Ile make ye all ſtinke with a
vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Why, ye worme-eaten ſlave, does my daughter looke like a Witch?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Budget, pray ye put downe worme-eaten ſlave, and the day of the moneth too, bee heare?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didſt not come thy ſelfe (you whorſon gull▪)

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye whoreſon gull.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didſt not come, thy ſelfe, I ſay to know what portion I wud give her? Now I find it was but a meere pretence, ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: If my man Hilts were here I wud beate thy very noſe into thy face, and afterwards beat it out agen.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What wud ye doe ſir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay pray gentlemen forbeare while ye are in my houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I can forbeare him no longer.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come ſit Timothy, pray goe along with me.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Sir Plenteous, pray ye goe along with me ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Prethee let me beate the rogue firſt.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay come ſir, come, come.

div.stage: Exit Muchcraft with Sir Thomas, Budget with ſir Plen.
Enter Sabina, Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Traſh, Rowland.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why ſo?
This is the crowne of all our joyes on earth,
When love and marriage trippe it hand in hand,
Jt makes the minde to vault
And caper o're the clouds of diſcontent;
Me thinkes my ſoule has wings and I cud fly,
From hence t' Elizium, come cheere up my ſweete,
What art thou ſad, and ſee thy husband laugh?
Come now we are married, we muſt have but one
Paſſion betwixt us — Gentlemen what?
Frownes at a Wedding?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: How? frownes?
Shud a man ſeeme to droope or hang the wings
At ſuch a time, he were farre fitter for
T'accompany wild Tygers in a wood,
Then to converſe with men, the gods themſelves
Sing Epithalamies, when mortals wed,
If Gods are ſubject to theſe paſſions, then
They needes muſt over-ſway the hearts of men;
Sir, joyes attend ye, may you ever be
As full of joyes, as we are now to ſee
Your happy Nuptialls:
Piſh, be not ſo ſad coſin.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Come leave this dull diſcourſe, and let us fill,
Our active ſoules up to the brimme with joy;
Come,

div.head: Sings.
div.l: FArewell this company,
If you love ſadneſſe,
For melancholy is,
Nothing but madneſſe;
Hang up proud coſtly cloathes,
Pedlers and pack toyes;
Let us make the hogs-heads weepe,
Claret and ſacke boyes.

sp.l: Are there no Fidlers in this world?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, I wud they wud come once, my very heeles are up ith' aire already me thinkes in this humour, I cud wiſh the whole world were a Morrice dance for foure & forty houres outright.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O thou egregious puppy, if the whole world were a Morris dance for foure and fortie houres outright, what ſhud, nay, what does thou thinke wud the good people of New England doe all that while.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I doe thinke they wud pray for a timely ceſſation of the noiſe of the ſuperſtitious bells hanging about their knees.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A moſt damnable witch in my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come ſweet-heart, ruſh up your ſpirits, put on a reſolution to be jocund; thinke but on what muſt paſſe betwixt us two this very night;
sp.l: How I muſt revill in thy armes, and then
How thou muſt tumble in my boſome;
And that I know will be enough to purge
Sad contemplations.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, pray you excuſe me;
Troubleſome thinges doe whiſper in my eare,
Which for the preſent J cannot expell.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Doe not heede or nuſle the leaſt ſad thought
At ſuch a time, tell 'em ſome other time
You'le ſit and heare their grievances.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Ay, ay, doe ſo, what? upon your joviall day be ſad? but where be theſe Fidlers?

sp.speaker: Muſi.
sp.p: We are come ſir.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Pray ye play then.
Come, a ſong, a ſong.

div.head: A Song.
div.l: IOy, health, and pleaſure, waite upon
This louely paire,
May all your dayes like to this one
Be void of care,
And may thoſe twinkling ſtarres of night
Attend your bed,
That ſo the bridegroome may get right
Your maydenhead.
And let Arabian odours then
Perfume thy ſheets;
Strewing thy chamber once agen
With daintie ſweets,
Then let theſe pretty thoughts that move
A flame in Cupids fires,
Bring ye to bed where you may prove
The things that love deſires.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come, theſe Nuptiall rites being done,
It now remaines we ſpeed it to the bed,
Where we will arme in arme diſcourſe and act
Loves pretty handy dandyes — Gentlemen
—ſpeake—
Has not my ſtarres beene kinde,
To grace my Fortunes with ſo faire a bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, ye enjoy a happineſſe beyond
Expreſſion or compare.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Nay ſir, Ile promiſe ye this, that as long as ſhe is your wife, no man breathing ſhall ere bring Acteons puniſhment
upon your head —I will not ſay what the woman may doe, and that's a rare bleſſing Rowland betwixt you and me, I can tell yee.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Me thinkes I ſee
My ſelfe now dandl'd on the knee of Fate.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, you doe now embrace
A richer veine than ere the Sunne beheld,
And I preſume none ſave your onely ſelfe,
Whoſe preſence is a treaſure of enchantments,
Could have prevail'd ſo farre with her, whoſe eye
Ne're yet caſt glance of love upon a man,
Therefore doe I pronounce
You th' onely minion both of Fame and Fate.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay, you are a happy man, that's certaine ſir, if all men had ſuch wives, we ſhud have a ſtrange world, for then we ſhud be troubled neither with children nor cuckholds.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well gentlemen golden ſlumbers attend ye,
Come faire one, come, we have too long defer'd
The love embraces of the marriage bed,
O how it rapps my ſoule to thinke that I
This very houre with my faire love muſt lie,
Rak't up in cinders, love may burne, but when
It 'gin's to flame, it fires both gods and men;
Come.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Pray ye ſir forbeare a little.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I will ſweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Coſin Fairefaith, a word, you have brought me here upon a buſineſſe will utterly diſgrace me; what will this gentleman thinke of me dee thinke, when he findes that I have gull'd him thus.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Come, come, put your feates to ſleepe,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay, come ſweete-heart, why theſe delayes?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Pray yee ſir deale gently with her, ſhe's yong and fearefull to lie with a man, and that's the buſineſſe ſir, that makes her ſo loth t'unpin.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Alas poore ſoule, in my conſcience you had rather lie with a woman, than with theſe rude men behalfe, wud not ye forſooth?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nothing? I know tis ſomething; are not y •• well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What's the reaſon yee will not goe to bed then? pray ye come without more adoe.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Fie upon't coſin, a woman wud ſcorne theſe things.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay, yee are ith' right ſir, I doe beleeve ſhe wud defie it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, what's the buſineſſe with ye? will ye not goe to bed —ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, Ile conſider of it preſently.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How, conſider of it?
Am I a man? a married man? or what?
Am I a husband? muſt a husband then
Entreate his wife?
Is Nature growne ſo old ſhe has forgot
To teach her children what belongs unto
Their different places?
Although before I was content to bend
My ſpirits to your foote, yet know, that now
The will of Fate has deſtin'd me to be
Next under it the ſole, commander of
Your minde and perſon, therefore now I muſt,
Nay, I will be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray ye doe not fright her too much, ſhe's a very tender hearted thing forſooth — pray ye ſpeake her faire.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Hold you your prating ſirra, ſhe ſhall obſerve my will now.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You'le never doe good ſir with foule meanes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: By your favour my friend, I know this out of my owne knowledge, that a froward ſharpe husband will preſently make a woman doe what ſhe liſt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Stoppe your mouthes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Sir, for my part I will not ſtop my mouth, I underderſtand
what I ſay ſir, I'me a married man my ſelfe ſir, and 'tis well knowne to be true, that I cud never yet get any thing of my wife by harſh words.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Once more I bid you hold your babling.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe ſhall not goe to bed till ſhee has a minde to goe to bed, nor I will not hold my babling neither ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold your peace Traſh.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You'le cloſe your mouth by and by I hope.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes marry will J ſir, but not at your bidding ſir: what now—what dee thinke I'me a foole in a Play?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Will you hold your tongue or no?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forſooth and pleaſe your worſhip.

div.stage: Sabina takes hold of him, and offers to ſtrike him.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: This inſolence I cannot beare,
And for your part you are my wife, and one
In whom obedience ought to be expreſt,
And I your top.

sp.speaker: Traſh.
sp.p: Ay, you want but a little whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What ſay you ſirra?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I ſay, a woman that has a good husband, and all things elſe, and will not goe to bed, wants nothing but whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well, 'tis thus,
If milde intreaties, nor a gentle fawne;
Nor proteſtations, nor a husbands love
Can mollifie thy Stubborneſſe, nor bring
Thy ſturdy diſpoſition to my hand;
Ile for a time quite turne out of my thoughts
A husbands pitties, and where ſmiles did faile,
A luſtie baſtinado ſhall perſwade
— What ſhall I be bafled thus
Out of my pleaſures with a womans bluſh;
Iſt fit that I ſtand pleading where my ſtarres
Bid me command? I ſcorne it, therefore ſpeake
This very preſent minute, nay before
You fetch more breath, ſpeake either ay, or no,
Or I muſt ſtrike, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: We ſhall have the Peace broken, here preſently, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Peace, quoth a? nay and my head be not broken I care not.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Come, ſhe is content to goe ſir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Give the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I will goe to bed.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come your wayes then.

div.stage: Exit Sabina leading Ʋalentine; Traſh falls into a laughter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Dee heare gentlemen, dee heare?
What if this gentleman ſhud get my Maſter with childe now?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Nay, what if your Maſter ſhud get that gentleman with childe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I cannot tell what hee may doe for men, but I ne're knew him doe ſuch a courteſie for a woman yet.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Mr. Fairefaith, pray tell me one thing, why did you being my Maſters kinſman, and an old ſouldier ſtand ſo patiently, and ſee him ſo affronted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: J that's true indeede Rowland, he being an old beaten ſouldier too.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A beaten ſouldier?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: An old ſouldier I meane ſir.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confeſſe I had no diſpoſition to medle in't, becauſe J know they'le agree themſelves, I know the bowels of the buſineſſe, which you doe not, come, goe along, and by the way Ile tell ye the plot.

lg.l: And then wee'le bring this newes
To bleſſe the eares of old ſir Timothy,
Strength I confeſſe may make a Gyant yeeld,
But give me policie to winne the field. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Mirabell, Hilts before, and Kate behinde.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O My poore ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: There's no queſtion but we ſhall finde her, how long has ſhe beene wanting forſooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A great while Kate, a little faſter, what ſhall I tread upon your heeles?—not ſo faſt neither.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p:
What the devill ayles ye? too ſoft, and then too faſt, here's more adoe with you, than with all the Pageants in
my Lord Majors ſhow; he that waites on you, had neede to have his ſteppes prick'd out with a paire of Compaſſes, for ought I ſee.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What a ſurly groome are you, may not one ſpeake to you?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Speake? yes forſooth you may ſpeake, but I doe not love to walke before a Gentlewoman like one of theſe gingerly youthes that goe before their Miſtreſſes, as if the ſtreets were pav'd with egges, not I.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why, how now ſir ſawce boxe, what is't all fellowes with ye, ye filthy, ſtinking, ſawcy, dirty, ſcabbed, paltry, louſie, mangie rogue ye.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Heyda, Miſtreſſe Iuniper, what's the matter with you tro? you were not us'd to be ſo ſnappiſh, I'me ſure on't, I have both gone and rid before you, and you ne're found fault with it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O ye lying raſcall, did ye ever ride before me in your life?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes marry have I forſooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: 'Tis as falſe a tale Miſtreſſe as ever was told; 'tis true, • e rid before me one night a little ſhort journey; 'twas nothing, I cud even a gone as farre a ſoote upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Who doubts that forſooth?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why will you lie then ye raſcall?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why, whats the buſineſſe? what the miſchiefe ayles ye? ſure ye have not made water today I thinke.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come Hilts come, you ſhud beare with her.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Beare forſooth, ſhee ſhud beare, ſhee's us'd too' it, more than I am forſooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What ſhud I beare pray? ſuffer ſuch an Aſſe as you to ride upon my backe, ſhud I not?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why not? aſwell as alwayes upon your belly forſooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, come, pray ye goe along, we have ſomething elſe to thinke on than ſtand here.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Very well ſir, I ſhall thinke upon your words.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: This way forſooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, yes, goe on.

div.stage: Enter Sir Timothy with officers meeting them.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How now daughter, whether are you going?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To ſee if I can finde my ſiſter ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, doe not trouble your ſelfe to no purpoſe, I have order'd it already, Ile have theſe men goe that have authority to make the doores and gates flie open where they come and goe, and dee heare Officers, looke too' it, and be ſure to ſearch very narrowly the places that I told ye of, and eſpecially the houſe where young Crambagge is ſuſpected to lie, and if yee finde either one or both of 'em, bring 'em away, dee heare?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.p: We ſhall ſir. Exeunt Officer.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Daughter, I rather thinke (to put her ſelfe out of th-way of this approaching diſparagement) ſhee has runne her ſelfe upon ſome deſperate courſe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But dee thinke theſe men will finde her ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I cannot tell, wee ſhall know preſently.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Doe not weepe Miſtreſſe, I hope ſhee's well, and will be here agen ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, lets have no weeping.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Doe not you greeve, and for them 'tis not a pinne matter, let them alone, weeping is as wholeſome for a woman ſir as making of water.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Had ſhe but bid farewell
'Twud not have troubled me ſo much;
But thus to goe away—

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Ne're feare, ſhee's well enough Ile warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Oh Hilts,
Her high borne ſpirit cannot brooke diſgrace,
And I doe feare theſe miſchiefes will provoke
Some violent hand upon her ſelfe;
yet me thinks one thing
Whiſpers my underſtanding in the eare,
And tells me ſhe is ſafe;
There's not a jewell, ring, or bracelet left
That ere ſhe wore, but is convey'd away.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Nay then ſir feare nothing, for if ſhee had ſo much wit to carry away her rings and jewells, ſhe has wit enough to keepe her ſelfe from killing or drowning, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: O heavens!
With what a ſwinge is youth,
Hurri'd along the world and ſubject ſtill,
Vnto the rule of an unbridl'd will:
Oh!
Pitty thoſe Parents then, who oftentimes
Are brought unto their graves by children crimes;
In, in, and comfort your ſelfe;
Ile ſee theſe Officers diſpatcht away,

div.stage: Exeunt Hilts, Mirabell, Kate at one doore, Sir Timothy at the other.
Enter Valentine unbutton'd as out of bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland▪ Rowland; I ſay.

div.stage: Enter Rowland as newly awaked.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What's the matter here?
Waſt you that call'd ſir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It was I.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: What wud ye have ſir, are not ye well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wud I were.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I'me ſorry you are not well ſir?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Call Traſh, call Traſh.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter? Within.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Come preſently, you maſter's not well;
Hes comming ſir, what wud ye pleaſe to have ſir?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing at all.

div.stage: Enter traſh yawning and rubbing his eyes.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, where art foole?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here, here man, whether doſt goe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter Rowland—ha?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your Maſter's not well here.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not well? O alas! Ile runne and fetch ſome hot water preſently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Stay, whether dee goe? come your wayes hither, what will you fetch man, I'me not ſicke.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not? you're but a yawling raſcall Rowland for waking of me, I was in the daintieſt ſleepe, and the ſweeteſt dreame; me thought my Maſter was in bed with the braveſt wench—

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: 'Twas too true.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? was it too true? introth, I thanke yee for nothing, you ne're dream'd ſo for me I'me ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, I'me undone, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: What's the matter ſir?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Ile warrant yee the gentleman that went to bed with him, finding himſelfe coſen'd has kill'd himſelfe, or one miſchiefe or other, I thought no good wud come on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas a woman all the while, 'twas a woman.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Twas a woman good man ſimple, what? doſt thou thinke that I dreame out of Aeſops Fables?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'Twud vexe a man to marry in jeſt, and then to have it prove plaine earneſt, Ile aſſure yee that.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: O Traſh, I'me undone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why undone ſir, why dee ſay ſo, and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Ime married man, I'me married with a vengeance,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why ſo am I too ſir; but how ſhud we helpe it, can ye tell that ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, what ſhall I doe? where ſhall I goe? where ſhall I runne?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Run quoth a? nay, if you'r married once, Ile truſt ye for running.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: I am married, and I know not to whom, did I but know that.

sp.speaker: Traſh.
sp.p: That's no great matter, 'tis but going to the Church Booke, and you may know that preſently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Accurſed Fate, what marriages might I have had? to what a pitch might I have mounted up my fortunes? which now I ſee are nothing but confuſion:
sp.l: Who knowes what ſtrumpet this may be,
Some queane for ought I know, that thinkes to raiſe
Her ſelfe out of my ruines:
Now my perplexed thought begin to burne
With flames of guilt:
Now comes my trembling ſoule unto the barre
Of my owne knowledge:
O Sabina, Sabina!
The gods now tumble vengeance on my head
For wrongs to thee;
Had I beene well advis'd, O then I might
Have layne by thy faire ſide, where every touch:
Had beene as tender as a bed of downe.
And every ſmile a heaven;
But 'tis too late,
To call backe what is paſt, it was my fate,
And there's an end;
Now am I round entrench'd with miſeries;
One ſide a marriage nips me in the bud;
On th'other ſide, a rankrous enemie,
Old Teſty, who ſtill gazes on the print
Of our miſtaken ſtep, therefore 'tis now
No time to pauſe, packe up my cloathes this night,
I doe intend to ſave my ſelfe by flight:
Traſh, about it preſently.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes and pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But dee heare, let not my Landlady, nor her husband have ſo much as a glimpſe of it, for I have no money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay ſir, if you intend to travell, be ſure ye take all your money along with ye, eſpecially if you meane to be merry, for you ſhall finde that money is the moſt daintie companion ſir; but Rowland, dee heare? ſcatter no words.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By no meanes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Not a word ſir;
sp.stage: Exeunt Valentine and Traſh, manet Rowland.
sp.l: Travell quoth a? here's a peece of worke indeede:
O Mr. Welt, how dee ſir, how does my Landlady —ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Very well, how dee you Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Troth, pretty well, Servingman like, careleſſe of much, proud of a little, drunke for want of wit, and ſometimes ſober for want of money.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thought ye had beene ſicke, becauſe I have not ſeene yee this long time.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Sicke quoth a? my pockets are a little cowardly now and then indeede, that's all my ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: What? wud ye have 'em quarrelſome?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Quarrelſome? no, but I wud have 'em to have a little more mettall in 'em for all that.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Wher's your Maſter pray?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay I know not, I have not ſeene him this ſixe houres.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: There is a little money due to me from him, I wiſh he wud take the payment of it into conſideration, I have exextraordinary occaſion to uſe the money, if he pleaſe to let me have but ſome of it, it will doe mee a courteſie, he ſhall finde me reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How idlely you talke husband? Is that a way to live in the world, doe you thinke it is for my eaſe to have gentlemen come, and lie in my houſe, and goe away and pay nothing — ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pay? yes good ſweetheart, why ſhud he not pay; there's no body ſpeakes againſt that, ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why doe you talke ſo fooliſhly then of being reaſonable, and I cannot tell what, I doe not like ſuch words I tell ye truely; —reaſonable quoth a? Eate my meate, drinke my drinke, burne my wood, foule my roomes, weare my ſheets, make uſe of my ſervants, and yet I muſt be reaſonable; if ye can talke no wiſelier before folkes, pray ye hold your peace and let your wife ſpeake — beſides, yee know he owes me both for bootes, ſhooes, and pantables, and I ſhall give him that too ſhall not I? no indeede forſooth, I wud have your Maſter to know that I do not buy my lether ſo cheape, Ile aſſure ye — be reaſonable quoth a? beſides, I have promis'd to pay Mr. Sugerbox the Chandler, nutmegges and ſugar for his mornings draughts, and Mr. Daſh the Vintener for wine in's chamber, and ſhall I pay them before your Maſter has paid me —introth I doe not meane it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'Tis fit a gentleman ſhud pay you before, that's the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ye ſay right Rowland, I ſee you have more conſideration with yee than my husband has — be reaſonable quoth a? —marry whoope.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Why dee keepe all this ſtirre, my Maſter's not running away woman — here's a quarter indeede, if hee will be ruled by me, he ſhall not give you one farthing, becauſe you keepe ſuch a coile.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
How keepe ſuch a coile ye jacke ſawee? how now? ſuch a coile? dee thinke ye are talking to your companions ſirra? ſuch a coile? and in my owne houſe too ſirra? and you
muſt ſtand by forſooth like Iohn a Noakes, and ſee every Servingman runne upon me in this manner; remember this when ye come to bed; and for your Maſters not paying of me, ye Sawcebox, I'me at the better end of the ſtaffe with him, for I have lockt up all his clothes; nay if you'r ſo Sawcy, Ile fit him, Ile warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Ye will?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes indeede will I?

div.stage: Enter Traſh.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland, Rowland, theeves, theeves, theeves, theeves, Rowland, theeves.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: All my Maſters clothes are ſtolne quite a way Rowland, all ſtolne every jot, breeches, doublet, boots, ſpurres, cloaks, gownes, hats, bands, cuffes, ruffes, caps, ſhooes, ſhirts, all gone, all ſtolne, every jot.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's the theefe.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here I ſay.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Who, my Landlady, did you ſteale my Maſters clothes — ha? wherefore pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Steale 'em? no ſir J ſcorne it; I tooke 'em indeede, and Ile juſtifie it; and more than ſo ſir, I have lockt 'em up, and Ile juſtifie that too.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? lockt up my Maſters clothes, wherefore I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wherefore? doe not yee know your Maſter owes me money? doe not you know I have often askt it, and cannot get it? doe not ye know that it is a pretty ſumme? doe not you know that it is for meate, drinke, lodging, fire, and candle-light, waſhing, wringing, and ſtarching; beſides, boots, ſhooes, pantables, and galoſheas: if, I had the Booke I cud ſhew ye.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, you're perfect enough without booke for ought I ſee. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Traſh, Your Maſter's come home, and you muſt come to him preſently. Exit Boy.

div.stage: Exeunt Traſh, Welt and his wife.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's a creature Ile ſweare upon a booke, this woman has no bones in her tongue, if any man love trumpets, there's a noiſe for him, ſure I doe not thinke but this Shoomaker's a witch, he wud never a contracted himſelfe to the devill elſe.

div.stage: Enter Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, are ye here? and I have nothing put up yet?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, your clothes are all put up, and ſafe under locke and key.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis no matter; who put 'em up?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: That did my Landlady ſir, ſhee has lockt 'em up, and ſweares ſhe'le keepe 'em ſafe till ſhe can perſwade ye to part with ſome pocket mettle ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Enough, enough, I will not be beholden to her, Ile ſatisfie her.

div.stage: Enter ſir Timothy with Officers.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O ſir, have I found ye out in the end, Come Officers lay hold on him — but ſtay lets talke with ye a little firſt.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sure my maſter was borne when the ſigne was in Cancer, for whatſoever he does intend, goes alwayes quite backwards, well ſome body ſhall know on't preſently, that ſhall fetch him off againe for all this ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Sirra, hold your peace, and
Be gone about your buſineſſe fellow, Exit Rowland.
Doſt know what thou haſt done? or have my wrongs
Arriv'd at thy underſtanding yet? — ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir I am conſcious to my ſelfe of all
The wrongs and injuries that I have done ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Why haſt thou put this blemiſh on my child,
Which like a Canker threatens to deface
My Story, and for ever raze my name
Out of the booke of honour, nay, a ſpot,
Which time nor date, nor all the briniſh waves
Can e're waſh out — ſpeake thou deteſted wretch;
Hadſt not a ſparke of vertue left within
Thy boſome to preſerve thy honour— ſpeake, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In trembling reverence to your precepts here,
I creepe upon my knees before the barre
Of Your juſt frownes, I dare not pleade excuſe,
No, no, my crimes are writ upon my front
In die of bluſhing guilt, which nothing but
Your reconciling ſmiles can ere waſh out,
—They, I ſay, they muſt be
That expiating ſacrifice for me.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Smiles on thee?
Haſt thou the face to ſay thy faults can be
Capable of mercy? go to, marke what I ſay,
Vnleſſe thou canſt contrive a way to cure
The wounded reputation of my Girle,
Expect not one commiſerating thought,
But all the tortours of ſeveritie
That e're can be inflicted —
Come, come, riſe up, it is in vaine to kneele,
My eares are ſtopt to mercy, nothing now
But onely that can ope them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am content to engage all my poſſibilities to accompliſh your deſires.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: There may be ſome hope in this.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.l: Sir, Deviſe how I may
But give this ſatisfaction you require,
And my ſoule ſhall ſtudy its performance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
Thou haſt ſo plung'd her in a ſincke of ſhame,
—That't will, for ought I know,
Nonplus the world to finde a remedie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her caſe is not ſo deſperate, I hope,
I'me ready here to hugge
The moſt ingenious torments on theſe termes,
That ſhe and you'le be pleas'd;
Wert to encounter a whole hoſt of fiends,
Never to ſleepe but in a Dragons den;
Or from the bowells of the burning hill
To fetch a cole, eate fire, or drinke a cup
Of Mercurie precipitat, Ile do't,
And thinke it an Eliſium, if it may
Redeeme your loves, and ſtate me once agen
In your eſteeme.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I doe commend your forward minde;
But this will never doo't;
There's nothing but a marriage will admit
A thought of remedy.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Nothing but marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Not any thing ith' world but Marriage▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No indeede.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Mercileſſe Planets, will ye ſtill goe on,
To heape theſe hills of miſchiefe on my necke▪
Or can misfortune reach a higher pitch
In him whoſe miſerie is intollerable,
And remedie impoſſible, O no;
Sir, in a word,
Your daughter's quite undone, and ſo am I.

sp.speaker: Sir, T.
sp.l: How ſtands the buſineſſe?
Speake the worſt, if truth, and let me die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis in vaine to counterfeit,
Or build up caſtles where they cannot ſtand;
Doe with me what ye pleaſe, the truth is this,
I am already married.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: How? already married?
Villaine, keepe in that breath;
The repetition of theſe words wud teare
A heart of braſſe—already married?
Didſt thou enſnare my childe for this?
Haſt thou betrayed her white innocence for this?
Blaſted the bloſſome of her virgin ſpring,
And married now another?
Canſt hope or dreame, that e're thy perjur'd ſoule
Shall ſee th' Eliſian groves?
Hold heart from breaking, now or never hold,
Married to another?
Shall I be bandy'd thus for ever twixt
Rackets of ſhame and miſery,
Cud fate finde ne're a football but my ſelfe
To toſſe and ſpurne—umph?
Hell and the furies doe conſpire I thinke,
To cull out me from all the reſt oth' world
To vent their miſchiefes on, who is't ye have married? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: It is unknowne to me ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I aske ye who 'tis you have married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir,
Vpon my life I know not who ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Has thy leudneſſe brought thee to diſtraction; married, and yee know not to whom? come take him away, 'tis in vaine to talke—but ſtay a little. Ile ſee what creature 'tis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis very true ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: What wilt thou make me mad?
Where is ſhe, in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Officer, goe fetch her hither, Exit Officer.
Ile make her tell me who ſhe is,
If ſhe can:
sp.p: Married already quoth a? and ye know not to whom neither, here's a marriage with a vengeance.

div.stage: Enter Fairefaith and Sportlove, who were preſent at the marriage leading betwixt them Sabina veil'd, they preſent her to her Father, Hilts attending them.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We heard ye ſent for my coſin Valentines wife ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We have brought her to you ſir, here ſhe is ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Very well, in good time: what are you gentlewoman? whence are ye? ha? — ſpeake; nay, if you will not give me an account, I muſt puniſh ye; Sabina unpins her maske, and falls upon her knees to her Father.
sp.l: — let not my eyes ſurfeit — what my Sabina?
My lovely Girle?
Thrice welcome to my boſome?
My Sabina? my daughter, and the wife
Of this my deared friend, unexpected felicitie,
sp.stage: Enter Sir Plenteous with Traſh and Rowland.
sp.l: Sir Plenteous? welcome thrice noble ſir Plenteous;
But ſtay
Gentlemen, pray ye preſent her to her husband firſt,
sp.stage: Fairefaith and Sportlove preſent her to Valentine.
sp.l: Sweet ſir Plenteous, how dee ſir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Dee know me ſir, nay gaze on ſir.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: He knowes her preſent I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Know her? he has beene familiarly with her—before man, and that thee didſt not know.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Gaze on ſtill ſir,
I'me not Sabinaes ghoſt, but her poore ſelfe;
Here ſtands the creature that was wrong'd by thee,
The very ſelfeſame that you married ſir:
What doſt thou thinke?
Doſt thou not tremble, leſt I ſhud begin,
To number up my wrongs?
I that was lull'd ith' boſome of my friends,
And as 'twere dandl'd on a Fathers knee;
Forfeited all this favour, and was made
A ſtranger to his eye for love to thee;
Yet thou
Like the prodigious Monſter of the world
Ingratitude, didſt labour to forget,
Not my love onely, but thoſe ſacred vowes
Have paſt betwixt us; but to be ſhort,
Thus —thus I revenge my ſelfe. Kiſſes him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my Sabina!
It is too ſweete and loving a revenge
Vpon ſo vile a miſcreant.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come
Let the remembrance of theſe matters dye,
And be confin'd to duſt, let 'em be trod
Into the very center of the earth,
Never to riſe againe; and let our loves
For ever twine like twins;
What's paſt I have forgot and pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Seale it, or elſe I die; Kiſſes him agen.
Live, O live!
A rare example to all future times
Of conſtancie in love.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Daughter, my heart bids thee welcome,
This night my houſe ſhall give thee entertainement,
Whereof thy ſelfe ſhall be ſole governeſſe,
And when the icie hand of death ſhall drive
My ſoule out of this clod,
It ſhall be his and thine.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: But gentlemen, me thinkes I long to heare
The ſtorie of this marriage, how it come to paſſe;
For did I know't, I ſhud adore the ſtarre,
Vnder whoſe influenee ſhe wae brought t'arive
Midſt ſtormes of woe upon this ſhore of bliſſe.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, I doe thinke 'twill be
A ſeaſonable diſcourſe for ſupper;
Suſpend but your deſires till then
And you ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: With all my heart, with all my heart, but ſonne, I have one petition to preferre to you.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: You may ſtile it a command ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: You muſt needs beſtow upon me your ſervant Traſh.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Heyda? now I'me a beg'd foole, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirra, attend my father.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your worſhips humble ſervant ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: In all this buſineſſe I have obſerved in thee
Diſcretion —judgement — wit—and police;
Therefore
I doe appoint thee Steward of my houſe,
And put into thy charge the overſeeing
Of all my buſineſſes.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay ſir, for an overſight in any buſineſſe let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: And what is more.
Diſpoſe my houſe and ſervants as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hilts, come hither —Sirra, doe you waite upon me.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I did ever thinke thou wudſt come to ſome good, for thou haſt beene alwayes an honeſt Trojan; Dee heare, if you had carried me to Bridewell, when ye were bid —where had your proferments beenethen Hilts.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Mr. Fairefaith, for you,
I doe perceive your ingenuitie,
Has beene a meanes to make my comfort ſwell;
And for returne, J doe beſtow on thee
My daughter Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, your returnes are farre beyond the claime
Of my deſerts; and though J am not fit
To bandy favours with ſo brave a Knight,
Yet I will ſtretch my ſtudes to expreſſe
A deteſtation of ingatitude: and now Sabina,
I doe ſalute thee by the word of Siſter, Kiſſes her▪
—but why ſo dumpiſh on a ſudden —ha?
I know the cauſe already, 'tis for feare
Your cenſures on her faults be too ſevere;
She has given ſatisfaction where 'twas due,
Her Father's pleas'd, and ſo we hope are you:
To you ſhe is referr'd, who now are ſet,
Ready to give your ſentences; but yet
Be pleas'd to ſpeake your doome with gentle breath,
Cauſe you're the Judges of her Life and Death.
